objects.author: Monica Kast
objects.title: University of Tennessee turns to at-home and wastewater tests to help stop COVID spike
objects.html:
The University of Tennessee at Knoxville will begin increasing COVID-19 testing on campus as the number of active cases continues to rise.

The university will begin testing wastewater from the residence halls, which will help identify any hot spots before they become clusters or large outbreaks, said Dr. Spencer Gregg, director of the Student Health Center. With additional testing, the number of active cases and isolations will likely increase, he said during Friday's COVID-19 update.

"With these measures, we're going to expect an increase in the number of positive cases and isolations ... and the need for quarantine," Gregg said. "Ultimately, the goal is just to reduce the incidents of both (cases and isolations)."

UT will also begin using at-home specimen tests to allow for more widespread testing, Gregg said. Currently, UT has been following CDC guidelines and only testing students who are symptomatic or close contacts of someone who has tested positive for coronavirus.

"Our hope is that by doing broad testing, we can identify new cases of the virus before it can spread and use the data to determine what systemic measures we need and where we need them," Chancellor Donde Plowman said.

The University of Arizona also uses similar wastewater testing. The university found early signs of COVID-19 in a dorm and was able to stop a larger outbreak. That would also be the goal of wastewater testing at UT, Plowman and Gregg said.

UT has seen nine clusters so far this semester, seven of which have been in sorority housing. The first cluster in a dorm was announced earlier this week. The second floor of the west wing of White Hall was a cluster after there were six connected COVID-19 cases, Plowman said.

All other students living in that wing are quarantining in place, she said.

UT Knoxville has 672 active COVID-19 cases and 2,079 people in isolation as of Sept. 10.

Creating additional isolation space on campus

Earlier this week, the university announced additional restrictions to try to help flatten the curve. Students living in Massey Hall will be tested for COVID-19 and moved out of the dorm, which will then be used for additional isolation space on campus.

Frank Cuevas, vice chancellor for student life, said Massey Hall was selected because it had the lowest occupancy rate on campus, under 70%, and also had the highest number of beds available for isolation housing.

More:University of Tennessee to move students out of Massey Hall to create more isolation space

"We recognize that this is a huge disruption for our students," Cuevas said.

The university has set up a call center and regularly scheduled Zoom meetings so students can contact the university if they have any questions or concerns about moving out of Massey Hall.

"We want to minimize the disruption of this transition as much as possible," Cuevas said.

New restrictions announced this week

The university also announced additional restrictions on campus, including no longer allowing visitors in dorms, making all dining carryout only and canceling all indoor on-campus events. These changes do not affect in-person classes or research, which will continue.

Plowman acknowledged that the additional restrictions make things on campus more difficult, but she said it will help slow the spread of COVID-19 and ensure the campus can stay open for in-person classes this semester.

"This is inconvenient, it's not fun," Plowman said. "It's not what college is usually about."

Additionally, the Tennessee Recreation Center for Students (TRECS) will be closed for two weeks. Though indoor in-person events are canceled for the next two weeks, virtual programming or programming that takes place outdoors can continue. The restrictions will be in place until at least Sept. 27.

"Any time that we can reduce the incidents of close contact, we're going to reduce the likelihood of infection spread," Gregg said Friday. "All these measures are directed to that goal."
